John--

Actually, the question was geared toward fiction writing -- hence =
the need for accurate detail.

The samurai philosophy is clear enough -- he=
aven knows, there are dozens of books about it.  But as a practical matter,=
 men wounded in battle had to be treated.  Willingness to die notwithstandi=
ng, a dead samurai (or ashigaru) is worth less to his master than a living =
one.  As I understand it, seppuku was reserved for hopeless situations, whe=
re the only other option was capture or abject failure (the death of one's =
daimyo, say).  

I imagine that battlefield medicine was very catch-as-catc=
h-can and based as much on Chinese medicine as was practical, but still, th=
e more specifics I can get, the better off I'll be.  Ditto info regarding d=
isposal of the dead after mass-casualty events.

And lest anyone think I'm =
some sort of poseur, I will say that I am an Active member of the Horror Wr=
iters Association (that is, a member considered to have professional creden=
tials) with a couple dozen published short stories to my name.  Just so's y=
a know.

Again, any details or good sources would be most helpful!

Thanks!=


Richard
